awd_titl_txt: Numerical Methods and Analysis for Interfacial Flow with Ionic Fluids and Surfactants
awd_abstract_narration:
This project is an investigation of fundamental problems in the dynamics of fluids, complex fluids, and deformable matter that occur in applications to biology and microtechnology. Its focus is on the development of new mathematical models and efficient numerical methods to study the morphology and control of drops, cells, and vesicles by electric fields in electrolytic fluids and by flow fields with surfactant. Electrokinetic techniques are among the most common methods for manipulating soft particles and ionic fluids in micro-scale and biological applications and can induce, for example, shape changes in cells and vesicles, from which membrane properties can be inferred. They can also induce membrane channel and pore formation for advanced cell treatment and therapy. Surfactants are used to enhance or control a wide range of complex fluid flows that occur in industries ranging from oil extraction to agriculture, food, and pharmaceutical processing. They are also important in microfluidic applications. Impacts of the proposed research include the development of new mathematical models and numerical methods that will be of benefit to scientists and engineers studying electrokinetic and surfactant phenomena in biology and engineering. An additional impact of this project is the education and involvement of graduate students. The interdisciplinary training they receive will be valuable preparation for a range of careers in mathematics and science.

During the deformation of a fluid-fluid interface with surfactant, surfactant exchange between the interface and bulk occur in a thin layer adjacent to the interface, and the layer's dynamics control interfacial surface tension and shape. During the interfacial flow of an ionic fluid that is driven by an electric field, a thin screening cloud of ions develops at the interface to form an electrochemical double layer or 'Debye layer'. The electric field induces motion in the ion cloud, the interface, and the surrounding fluid. The influence of surfactants on interface and flow dynamics and the occurrence of 'induced-charge electrokinetic flow' in an ionic fluid are both important phenomena in a wide range of applications. This project addresses a difficulty in the numerical computation of such flows in the practically important limit of thin surfactant exchange layers and thin electrical double layers, by developing fast and accurate 'hybrid' or multiscale numerical methods that incorporate an asymptotic analysis of the layer dynamics into a boundary integral or similar formulation of the interfacial free boundary problem. Central themes of the current project are the development of a hybrid method for electrokinetic flow about a deformable membrane and the investigation of fast and accurate numerical methods for studying the influence of surfactant and ionic surfactant on interfacial flow. The algorithm for electrokinetic flow will incorporate an analysis of the high-wavenumber or small-scale component of the elastic and electrostatic stresses on a membrane into a nonstiff method that is capable of handling the multiple time and space scales inherent in the problem. The method will be used to study canonical problems in the deformation of drops, vesicles, and cells, and to explore the interaction between membrane and ionic fluid properties. In the context of surfactant-laden flows, the hybrid numerical method will be developed to accurately handle multiply connected domains with close interaction of interfaces, such as occurs with multiple drops, and the presence of surfactant in the interior fluid, both of which are associated with substantial numerical challenges. This project also involves the development of fast or accelerated algorithms, including for drops in 3D flow with soluble surfactant, as well a fundamental analysis of the stability and convergence of the boundary integral methods that are a cornerstone of this work.

por.por_cntn:
This project considered fundamental moving boundary problems from fluid dynamics that are motivated by applications to biology and microfluidics. The PIs, with their students and collaborators, developed new multiscale models and efficient numerical methods for investigating (i) the dynamics of cell and vesicle membranes in ion-containing fluids with imposed electric fields, and (ii) interfacial flow with soluble surfactant. Surfactant and electric fields are among the most important mechanisms for the control of fluid dispersions.

The methods developed by the PIs address significant difficulties in the numerical computation of interfaces in ion-containing fluids in the practically important thin Debye layer limit, and in fluids with soluble surfactant in the large Peclet number limit. In each of these scenarios, a thin transition layer develops near the interface in which physical quantities rapidly vary, which is challenging to resolve in numerical computations.

To address this difficulty, in (i) the investigators derived two new macroscale electrokinetic models for flow about a deformed drop or vesicle-cell membrane by taking a specific thin Debye layer limit of the coupled Poisson-Nernst-Planck (PNP) and Stokes equations.  In electrokinetics, charge-carrying ions are plentiful and present in a thin diffuse charge cloud next to a surface, known as a Debye layer.   The abundance of ions is typical of aqueous solutions of strong electrolytes. Applied fields of a few volts per centimeter are sufficient to act on this charge cloud and induce flow. 

The new macroscale electrokinetic models developed by the PIs are a main result of this project and describe the deformation of (i) a drop interface that separates two immiscible electrolytes and (ii) a membrane, such as an inextensible lipid bilayer, that separates regions of a single electrolyte solution and is only slightly leaky to ions, so that it allows a small flux of ions through its interface. 

The PIs additionally developed an accurate and efficient boundary integral numerical method to simulate their macroscale drop model.    This enables numerical simulations of electrokinetic flow for thin Debye layers, for which computation of the PNP-Stokes equations would be intractable.

The PIs and collaborators also developed an accurate and efficient boundary integral method to simulate a simplified model of electrokinetic flow in the Debye-Huckel regime.  The numerical method was used to study the effect of Debye layer thickness on the breakup of an electrolyte drop subjected to an imposed electric field.

In the surfactant problem (ii), one of the PIs and collaborators developed a boundary integral (BI) method for computing the evolution of multiple surfactant-covered droplets in 2D Stokes flow that maintains high accuracy even when droplets are in close proximity. This is a well-known difficulty for BI methods. 

The PIs have also significantly extended a `hybrid’ numerical method for soluble surfactant, which they previously developed.  The hybrid method uses the slenderness of the transition layer to incorporate a separate analytical reduction of the layer’s dynamics into an accurate boundary integral numerical solution of the interfacial free boundary problem.  The extensions are (i) treatment of systems of drops in which the bulk concentration of soluble surfactant is present in the drop interior, and (ii) implementation of a novel causal version of the Fast Multipole Method to construct the solution for the bulk surfactant concentration C in terms of a time-convolution integral. The development (i) resolves a significant challenge in the hybrid method for interior flow caused by recirculation of the flow inside a drop. The improvement in (ii) gives a novel fast mesh-free method for finding the solution in the transition layer that can greatly reduce the computational overhead that is needed for problems with soluble surfactant in complex 3D geometries. 

Related results obtained with collaborators include the derivation of a drag formula for the translational motion of a disk embedded in a nearly-inviscid  Langmuir film of surfactant, which is a classical problem dating back to Saffman (J. Fluid Mech. 73 (1976)).   The first convergence analysis of the boundary integral method for interfacial Stokes flow of drops, bubbles, and elastic capsules has also been provided. This analysis clarifies the role of numerical filters for stability.

Other work includes analytical and numerical studies of finite-time singularity formation in the generalized Constantin-Lax-Majda (gCLM) equation, which has received intense interest as a simplified model for singularity formation in the 3D Euler equations.  Results include the first detailed investigation of singularity formation in the gCLM equation for a wide range of parameter values.   The PIs have also developed analysis and accurate numerical methods for Stokes flow with mixed boundary conditions, which arises in models of flow over superhydrophobic (or `slippery’) surfaces.
